text: hi everyone anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd i hope
you're doing well
and it's time for a review of this new
album from the body
i've seen all i need to see this is the
latest full-length lp from one of the
heaviest
noisiest and most abrasive bands in
drone
sludge and noise the body been aware of
the band for about 10 years now and over
that course of time
they've built an impressive catalog of
albums eps and collaborations with the
likes of uniform
thou as well as full of hell it's a
truly
unforgiving catalogue that i have
admired
more in concept than in practice though
there are so many things to appreciate
about the body sound whether it be their
crushing rifts
primal drums creative use of noise and
distortion
unorthodox production tactics as well as
some ambitious
instrumental inclusions whether they are
incorporating some strings or chorus
vocals on some of their stuff
and while all that is great the one
thing that's held me back from
loving the body's music as much as i
feel like i could
it's the vocals which might seem like a
cop-out in the case of the body or
really disliking any artist's music
really but
i don't know their tracks are usually
topped with this unintelligible shriek
that is quite strange and persistent and
in many cases i don't feel this adds to
the horror of their sound
more it distracts from it but honestly
this has been my opinion for quite a
long time
and this has also been the body's
approach to vocals for quite a long time
and i i don't think that's going to be
changing anytime soon that being said
though i do still find the band's
records generally
intriguing and always worth a try
especially the collaborations
but i was surprised to find that i've
seen all i need to see
was really clicking with me the more
that i listened to it in fact
and sure those shrieks that i was
talking about earlier
are still here in spades but there are
some trade-offs into
some more direct screened vocals on the
record
and they're also maybe a bit more buried
in the mix on this one too
or at least maybe the riffs and
distortion are a bit
louder so that as a factor is kind of
swallowing everything else in the mix in
fact i think this project might be the
most abusively
loud distorted and compressed the body
has released to date
this thing is so freaking loud the thick
viscous
walls of distortion packed into every
track here
just shiver under their own weight and
also
squeeze to death every other sound
existing between them on any given track
even the intro where the symbols are
just like
shaking violently in between like these
walls of distortion
also the ascending post-rockian melodies
toward the end
of the track that are a very nice touch
so it's a killer beginning to this
record
things turn even more savage though on
the following
tied up and locked in which features a
lot of similar elements the drums
the vocals the unforgiving riffs that
are so obliterating
and distorted they feel like the force
of a nuclear
blast hitting you but that force that
wave that push
never ends it's just forever
but what makes this track a little
different a bit more intense is the
pace is picked up the riffs have more of
a head-banging quality to them
and the whole track runs this play where
it just gets more and more distorted
and hideous as it plugs along by the
time it's done the whole thing sounds
like it's just burnt to a crisp
eschatological imperative
has easily some of the most gargantuan
and panoramic riffs that i've heard in
quite a long time the whole thing is
pretty simple and straightforward
compositionally which is nothing
entirely new
for the body as their songs do tend to
run
very slow but the sound is just too
immense
for words i think things do tone down a
little bit on the following
a pain of knowing which to me sort of
just sounds like
a straightforward meat and potatoes
drone
doom track very sun inspired of course
the bodies trademark vocals are in the
mix but outside of that if they were
completely
pulled out of the equation yeah it would
just sound like an old sun track
and sure it is engineered and recorded
well like the distortion and bass are
incredible but
it's not reinventing the wheel or
anything the city is shelled has almost
a similar progression to tied up and
locked in mesmerizing riff constant
groove
and it just gets progressively more and
more noisy cacophonous
intense by the end of it the sound of
this thing is so fried
the symbols just sound like hissing
white noise
the cycling and throbbing electronics
that introduce themselves
very aggressively in the second half are
a nice touch too to just add some
extra texture to the whole thing uh with
it sounding as loud as it was at that
point i'm surprised that
the body had found space in the eq and
in the mix to throw in
another thing what's even nicer are the
harsh vocals and harmonious tones that
build up in the second half and
bring the entire track to an apocalyptic
but beautiful
finale the handle the blade features a
lot of constant
distorted droning as well as tense
drumming it's got a quick pace to it
sort of sounds like a chase scene in a
horror movie though maybe one where
nothing happens as the
ending seems to fizzle out pretty
anticlimactically and the closer while
it may not be one of my favorite tracks
here does have its moments as well
especially during the midpoint where
the track essentially sounds like these
wild drum improvisations set to a subtle
distorted drone
and um what i could only describe
as like thunderclaps coming down
just raining down onto the song i mean
of course like
this is some crazy distorted noise
the body are
generating for this particular track but
like the more i listen to it the more it
really does sound like some
thunder just crashing in that's pretty
much the track list of the album it's
very straightforward
it's very trim i would also say if
you're not sold on this thing by the
first few tracks you know it's it's not
necessarily going to
win you over with the rest of it i think
the body
gives listeners a pretty direct and
clear idea of what they're going to be
doing on this record
pretty immediately and again the noise
the distortion
the engineering are all incredible but
if there's one thing i could take away
from this project that maybe other body
albums
have as an advantage is that this record
is
is not one of their more instrumentally
diverse
projects to date but with that being
said though i do think the band finds a
respectable amount of versatility in
all of this harshness i'm feeling a
decent two strong seven
on this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
